Predict the Spead - Part of Coleco's pre-game fun is predicting the spread. Guess the spread between opposing teams - closest to the actual result takes all.

Predict Each Quarter Score - Dial each quarter score - before the start of the quarter - and get your chips down. At the end of the each period, someone wins!

Show Your Colors on Every Play - You decide, and declare yourself on these strategic questions, ahead of every play you'll view on TV:
Will it be a pass?
Will the pass be completed?
If complete, how many yards?
Will it be a run?
For how many yards?
Will it be a first down?
Will it be a touchdown drive or not?
Kick a field goal?
Plus - show your savvy on punt and kickoff return yardage.

Game contains: 1 four color game board, poker chips, 2 football shaped chips holders, 1 solitaire score pad, and 1 instruction sheet

name: Tartars and Martyrs
description: An experimental, skeletal Microgame published in issue 20 of the Space Gamer, this game might have been expanded into a full microgame in the future based on reader input. In it, five European religious martyrs attempt to convert five Tartars before being killed. Martyrs cannot fight, but converted Tartars can. Vitality of units and success of "attacks" are determined by die rolls.

name: Coast to Coast
description:
From the box: "Travel across Canada and the United States from East to West. Follow the traffic rules all the way... Have a good time."

A rather simple game using where players race across North America from the east coast (starting at St. John's, Sydney, Charlottetown, or Yarmouth) and ending at the west coast (Prince Rupert, Vancouver, San Francisco, or Los Angeles). As players travel, they make choices as to which path to take. Green stops on the path affect the players (Engine overheats, miss a turn" or "Finish at this San Francisco". Players may not pass another player on a route unless a player is stopped on a Red (actually Orange on the board) stop which represents a major city, or a player has been penalized by a green stop. The first player to the west coast wins.

Components include a foldable gameboard with a map of North America on one side marked with the various routes and stop points, 4 pawns, two dice, and a single rule page that includes both English and French instructions.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Revenge From Beyond, An R.I.P. Card Game
description:
Card game that came with the R.I.P. Comics Module #8.

Each player draws a victim card and 2 clue cards, while the 5 murderer cards are placed face down on the table. Players take turn to draw a card, and discard or play a card, either in front of their own victim or in front of another players victim. Once the player reaches enough points, they are allowed to examine one of the murderer cards. Once you find your own murderer you win the game.

name: Cities
description:
Cities is a simple, old rummy-style card game with a 54 card deck consisting of 3 cards sets of 18 cities. The object of the game is to collect all three cards for a city--CHI/CA/GO, for example--which is scored based on the city's population. (The game is from 1932, so Houston is half the size of Milwaukee!)

Each card contains picture of a famous building and a brief factoid about the city--did you know that Pittsburgh has (had?) more viaducts than any city in the world?

name: Supermarket
description: In Supermarket, shoppers are limited to a strict budget which they must spend for food either in the Supermarket or in neighborhood stores. While en route to the market areas either on foot or by taxi traffic signals must be observed.

name: Peter Pan Card Game
description:
The game is based on the card game WHIST.
First published with green backs to the cards, but later with red backs.

name: Film Fantasy Card Game
description: Movie related card game from the late 30's early 40's. The game consists of 45 cards depicting scenes from 11 films including "Lucky Night", "Goodbye Mr Chips", It's A Wonderful World", Ice Follies of 1939", "Bridal Suite", Idiot's Delight", "Serenade", Calling Dr. Kildare" "The Lambeth Walk", The Hardys Ride High" and "Tarzan In Exile" . The cards have illustrations in full color made from photographs taken during the production of the films.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Highway Patrol
description:
In this game one player takes on the role of the bandit and is given a card showing which of the 6 hideouts are his real location for this game. The other players all play highway patrol men trying to catch the bandit in action as he sets out to commit robberies and get back to his hideout. The patrol men are also given cards to randomly determine their starting locations on the board. The game includes a board with 3 spinners on it, the bandit always uses spinner #1 which gives the most possible movement. The spinner used by the patrol men is dependent upon how many players are in the game. The more players the slower the spinner.

The goal of the game for the bandit is to make 3 robberies, returning to his hideout between each of them. The bandit must announce which type of crime he is committing giving the patrol men an idea where he may be. The patrol men have to end their movement on the bandit's location. The patrol men have special items they can use in their search for the bandit such as road blocks and the use of a helicopter.

name: Star Raider
description:
A game of interstellar exploration and colonization for 2-3 players. When a new system is explored, a card is drawn to determine its value; there may be native forces or other things to be dealt with. In the basic game, there are two forces - the black and the red. The black has large numbers, while the red has a much smaller fleet of faster ships. Speed is very important, since faster ships can retreat from combat from slower ones unless attackers move in from all six adjacent hexes. The red force also has battlecruisers, which have the speed of a cruiser and nearly the combat strength of a battleship. There is a blue fleet for a third player, identical to the red fleet.

In addition to spaceships, there are several types of ground forces with which to contend for control of systems.

The map has star systems scattered across it, and many nebulae, which slow movement.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Events, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Simulation, Three Dimensional Movement

name: Holly Hobbie The Windy Day Game
description: Another of the short line of Holly Hobbie games put out by Parker Brothers in the late 1970s. This one is for 2 to 4 players, Ages 4 - 8 Holly and her friends' hats got blown away on a windy day; now the players must get them back. The object is to collect exactly six different hats at one time.

name: Winecellar
description:
"Winecellar: The Vintage Board Game that explores the wonders of wine - for tasting, toasting and cooking."

A Monopoly-style roll-and-move game where sets of four cards for each of 40 wines are collected. Points are scored based on variety and numbers of cards held plus/minus bonuses.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Logik for begyndere
description: A logical thinking game where you answer yes, no or gibberish to the questions asked. An example of a question is “Can a striped glove, which has a checkered pattern, have three colors?" If the question is contradictory and you can't answer yes or no then gibberish is the right answer.

name: Scholar Venture
description:
This is the now OOP self-titled boardgame from Scholar Venture. They now make card games (Pimps & Hos, You Go to Hell!, Who Really Has The Huevos?). As far as # of players, I'm not quite sure what "Up to 6 teams of 2 or 3" means, so I am entering 4-18, which is my interpretation.

2002 Mensa nominee for best mind game.

Manufacturer's Blurb:

Scholar Venture: Brain power, chance and role playing combined in one challenging and often hilarious new board game. The first team to collect $250,000 and land their little 'Brain Pawn' on the 'Graduate School' space is 'The Winner'. Answer Trivia Questions in varying degrees of difficulty and win $ when correct. Pay out $ if you answer incorrectly.

Choose a 'Scholar Experience' and take a chance. You could win big! But you could lose a bunch. You never know.
'Take the Venture' as your team plays out unique real life situations that could earn you $ and will definitely get you 'laughs'.

Be the next Albert Einstein, or even the next Robert Deniro or Julia Roberts. Scholar Venture: The board game that teases your brain and tickles your funny bone.

Ages 14 and up - Up to 6 teams of 2 or 3.
Suggested retail price: $32.95. Check us out at www.scholarventure.com

name: Constructopolis
description:
A magazine game from Jeux et Stratégie #58.

Two to six real estate speculators try to enrich themselves while pushing their competitors into bankruptcy.

name: Becherspiel
description:
Lovely looking Egg and Spoon Race set. Long wooden holders with a ball at one end to hold. Matching wooden ball to sit in the cup at the end.

Ages 4-99

name: Maurice Sendak's Little Bear Make-a-Match Game
description: Ages 3 and up. Each player is given a mat with 9 pictures on it, which are labeled. The players take turns taking cards, either from the top of the draw pile, or the last one discarded. If a player gets a card that matches one of the nine pictures on his mat, he places the card on top of that picture on his mat. If he gets a card that he does not need, he discards it. The first player to cover all 9 pictures on his mat wins. Alternately, the game can be played by matching the background color of the card chosen to the background colors on the mat, rather than matching the picture. For older children, there are also mats with letters of the alphabet on them. To use these, the players match the picture on the card drawn with the first letter in its label.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Tales of Wells Fargo Game
description:
Each player controls a posse of two cowboys out searching for stolen valuables. The object of the game is to collect the most reward money by retrieving the valuables. When an item is located, it must be returned to the Holdup Scene to collect the reward. If another cowboy is able to catch up with the posse bringing an item to the Holdup Scene, that cowboy may join up and share in the reward.

If the game sounds familiar, there is a reason. Milton Bradley essentially repackaged its Hopalong Cassidy game for this venture. The Tales of Wells Fargo Game uses the same 8 metal horses, 12 discs (albeit with lower reward values), and even the same custom spinner.
categories: Adventure, American West, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Boston in a Box
description:
A game similar to Monopoly based on Boston - Buy property, build a skyline, trade the skyline for a key to the cite. It sounds easy enough but add a traffic jam, excise tax, car fines, and the IRS and it becomes a little more difficult and a lot more fun

Cards include:
Advance to the home of the famous grasshopper. Don't know? Don't go!
Name 4 North End festivals or Lose 1 turn
You're caught throwing tea in the harbor! Place $20 fine in the center of the board.
Your chowder is voted best in Boston! Collect $20 from each player for the recipe.
Heartbreak Hill! Move back to Boston Marathon and Lose 1 turn.
Return of the Swans! Advance to Public Gardens


Tokens are: pretzel, heart, Boston Terrier, swan boat, tea barrel, tri-corner hat

Board spaces include: JFK Library & Museum, Mr. Dooley's Boston Tavern, The "T", Beacon Hill, New England Aquarium, Fenway Park, Old North Church and more

Game includes a game board, 6 tokens, skyline sections, keys to the city, Big Fun! & Contingency cards, deeds, play money, 2 six sided dice, and instructions
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Armatac II
description:
From the inside cover page of the books:

"The ARMATAC II system is a component system which allows the player to purchase books and playing pieces as they are needed, to recreate the battles and campaigns of World War II. The players create armies of different sizes and nationalities and must use all of the skill and knowledge of strategy they possess to defeat their opponents. Rules are provided on how to play the games, but these can be looked upon as guidelines. It will constantly be stressed that this is your system and the rules can be altered to suit your particular style of play. The games can be played as simple or complicated as you prefer. Because of the endless variety of combat situations which can be constructed, we hope players will never tire of the system."

"We offer 5 books within the system, each one covering 300 weapons. There are 2 aircraft books, 2 naval books and 1 armor book. This means a total of 1,500 weapons are covered. A total of over 1,000,000 of these weapons were produced and we provide production figures for all of them. Our playing pieces are larger than those offered by other gaming companies and are presented in a variety of shapes which look like the weapons they have been chosen to represent. Our playing pieces are available in four different 4 color camouflage patterns. A national insignia sheet is also available in full color and contains over 500 insignias from over a dozen countries. When applied to the playing pieces, these insignias combined with the size, shape and camouflage patterns provide an air of realism and excitement never before attainable at the price they are offered."

"Because of the larger size of our playing pieces, it stands to reason our hexes must be larger to accommodate them. In keeping with our policy of non-restriction, a stencil is available within our system which allows the player to trace this hex pattern across any playing surface they choose. A readily available and inexpensive playing surface is poster board (22" x 28"). Two of these boards butted together make a good beginner size and three boards make a good overall size for any type of gaming activity. These boards can be left plain, or full color scenarios can be drawn on them prior to tracing the hex pattern. Even those players with limited artistic ability can create personalized scenarios with a little time and patience. Maps can be purchased of oceans, continents and individual countries. These maps are relatively inexpensive, are good size for gaming and make for an extremely attractive playing surface. County survey maps can also be acquired, as well as city and county street indexes for those who wish to engage in street fighting. A hex pattern sheet is also provided with our stencil which can be inexpensively reprinted at your local quickie printer."

"A map or scenario can also be applied to a window shade and our design traced across it. The shade can be stretched across the playing area and retained at the ends while in use. For those with a permanent playing table, shade brackets can be attached to one edge of the table and the shade snapped in. The pull tab can be retained at the opposite edge with the aid of a nail. In this way the shade will rest squarely on the table top and remain taut. A variety of shades can be prepared and used as they are needed. This should be especially appealing for clubs. Games can also be played on non-hex surfaces by simply substituting inches for hex speed, which is contained in the WARGAME CHARTS. Remember, we will recommend how the games should be played, but the final decision is up to you."

name: Tchernobyl-sur-Loire
description:
A magazine game from Jeux & Stratégie Nouvelle formule #6.

2 to 4 industrial conglomerates try to get as reach as possible be developing polluting industries and manipulating ecologists to check other conglomerates' development.

name: Rocket Race
description: Rocket Race is one of the Milton Bradley "Flipsiders" games that resembles an audio cassette until you "flip" the game open. The 2 players (starting at either Earth or Mars) compete to race their rockets to Pluto and back. On your turn you move your marker across the board the number showing on either spinner. The A spinner requires you to spend a fuel unit to use (you can refuel by landing on a planet). The B spinner only lets you drift 0 or 1 space. It is used if you are out of, or trying to conserve fuel. You might also spin an Explosion which causes you to lose all your fuel. Go to Pluto and return to your home planet first to win.

name: Fluppy Dogs
description: This is a simple childrens memory/matching game based on the Disney cartoon characters. The board is a slotted raised platform that sits in the box. The 24 Fluppy Dog cards each depict 2 dogs (an upper and a lower) of various colors. These cards are inserted into the board slots to hide the lower dogs. On your first turn you draw a card and keep it to start your chain. From then on when you draw a card, if the color of the lower (hidden) dog matches a color at either end of your chain, you connect it (ala dominoes). If the color does not match, you place it back in a board slot. Thus you need to remember where hidden Fluppy Dogs are put back so you can find the ones you need to make a color-match. The first player to collect 5 cards in his or her chain is the winner.
categories: Children's Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Military Chess
description:
An abstract military-themed game. Uses a modified 64-square chess board divided by a river crossable at four bridges. Each side also has two minefields on its side of the battlefield. Each army has 12 hard plastic pieces depicting various soldiers or weapons. There is a "General" (chess King), two "Cannon" (moves like a chess king but can "fire" at enemy pieces up to three squares away instead of moving), one "Tank" (chess Rook), one "Bazooka-man" (can move up to 3 squares in any direction), one "Jeep" (same as the Bazooka-man), two "Infantry" (can move up to two squares in any direction) and four "Advanced Guard" (can move up to two squares in any direction EXCEPT backwards.)

The object of the game is to eliminate the opposing general or move your own general to the other end of the board.

The game was originally marketed by A.N. Meyers & Co. (London) as a "New Game for the Chessboard" in the 1880's.
publishers: (Public Domain), A. N. Myers & Co, Military Games

name: Goats on Boats
description: Goats on Boats is a children’s memory matching tile game. The player that matches the most goats on boats pictured tiles wins. Game came be played solo, it also has several goat and boat facts on the back of each piece.

name: Main Street
description:
This game has a series of 5 different games for players of varying ages.

From the rules:

"Like its predecessor, GOOD OLD HOUSES, this game focuses player attention on specific architectural details and on the stylistic variety of historic buildings. MAIN STREET, however, brings attention to downtown buildings, structures which, in the hustle and bustle of commercial life, escape the notice of even frequent passers-by. Our illustrations show each style with its original storefront, but because storefronts are periodically remodeled, one is lucky to find historic storefronts intact. MAIN STREET players will find themselves looking at the upper levels of commercial buildings to recognize styles they have learned in the game.

The range of styles in MAIN STREET from Federal to Art Deco/Modern, isn't intended to encompass the breadth of American Architectural history, but to represent some basic styles often used in commercial buildings between the late eighteenth and mid-twentieth centuries.

The eight building puzzles (nine pieces per puzzle) are used in five different games for 1 to 8 players Ages 5 and up."

name: Metropolis
description:
Long flat box, only two pages of rules. Drive cars around a city (roll a die to move) and purchase building lots of various values (green - highest, yellow - middle, red - lowest) and types (plaza, industrial, apartment, municipal, business). Hard board map depicts building lots, and various movement effect spaces (stopping arrows in different directions and configurations) - you collect money and can change direction of movement). When you purchase the lot you take the card for that lot.

You subsequently build on those lots based on certain restrictions (eg. 3 undeveloped residential lots can be built over if you buy a plaza lot). Subsequent activities include auctioning, mortgaging, trespass fines.

Pretty basic looking as a game. Out of print.

Contains 48 plastic buildings.

name: Chicken Soup For The Soul
description: (For 2-6 players or team play-Ages 9 and up) Inspired by the #1 Bestselling Books! Chicken Soup for the Soul The Game. It's "Condensed Soup Recipe" for gameplay- 1. Pick a card, 2. Roll the die, 3. Do what the card says to collect a card and to move your token. The game consists of the following "ingredients": 1 game board, 200 cards (4 decks in different colors), 6 tokens, 1 pencil, 1 pad, 1 Chicken Soup die, 1 tsp. of humor, pinch of wisdom, dash of friendship, a generous portion of love. The object of the game is to be the first player to collect 8 cards, 2 from each deck. And while you're doing that enjoy the experience of sharing, friendship and laughter.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Arns rike
description: You play the Swedish knight Arn Magnusson. The game lets you discover how life was in the 11th century.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Anker spill
description: The players place a plastic ring on their nose which has a line with an anchor on it. You then try to catch small rings which are placed on the table with the anchor.

name: Happy Day
description: This is a simple card game with a "Crazy Eights" type mechanic. The object is have the happiest day. There is a board with 9 play areas. Chips are placed above the areas with their point values face down. Each player receives 5 cards. To start, you play a Yucky Day card (such as "Fly in your cereal...") onto the first area and inform any other player that he or she will experience the yucky event shown. That player must then try to match the card with either another Yucky Day card of the same color and number, or a Happy Day card which is wild. A new player is called on who again must match the new card. The first called on player who cannot make a match loses the round and must take the chip for that area. New cards are then dealt out for the next round and players play them into the next area. When all 9 rounds have been played, the player with the lowest point value on all of his or her chips had the happiest day and wins.

name: Bankerott
description:
Each player has a pot of gold which you have to defend from the other players attack. This is done by placing number and action cards on the table. Whoever gets all the gold wins.

The game is about avoiding going over the number 21 when it's your turn to play a card in the common deck. The cards consist of number cards 0-5 and various action cards that can modify the number level.

If you end up over 21 or if one player play their last card, you will lose part of your fortune. If you lose everything, you are bankrupt and out of the game. The winner is the player who is left alone in the end.

name: Official Skins Golf Game
description: The object of this game is to get the least amount of strokes and the most amount of Token$. Every hole is worth at least one token from every player. The player must win the hole outright in order to collect the token from green. If two or more players tie on a hole with the lowest score, the hole is a "Push" and all tokens will be carried forward to the next hole. Remember there is an ante of 1 token for each hole, and every players gets the opportunity to win all carry overs.

name: Jernteppe?!
description: Trivia game with 3200 questions, where the questions are based on funny expressions.

name: Nya barngeni
description: Trivia game for children. Includes 1200 questions in six categories.

name: Ombytta roller
description: A game for men and women where both parties try to guess how the other part would react in a given situation.

name: La Dernière maison sur la gauche
description:
Published in the Xmas special issue of Plasma (n°15).

During April 8th 1945, last survivors of the Leibstandarte Adolf Hirler and of the Hitlerjugend struggle one last time in the little town of Wiener-Neustadt, a few kilometers south of Vienna.
Facing them, the best elements of the Soviet Guard 6th Army. One the houses on the outskirts of the town is the place of violent fights. All the night, the combat moves from room to room and the last combatants kill each others in the most grim ways.

It is now April 8th 1995 and the soldiers who died that night come back to reenact, as they do each year, the fight that occurred.
Hatred is the energy that make them live.

.....................

Each player has 5 undead soldiers. One player controls the undead Soviets, the other the German ones.
They fight on a map of the house (garden and first floor, square cases, not hexagons).
Hatred influences the Action Points pools and other game mechanics. Each player has 50 hatred points he uses as 'fuel' for his characters.

Uses a D6.

name: How Silas Popped the Question
description: An earlier version of Mad libs with phrases printed on standard sized cards that are spread face down on the table. Players take turn reading the Story on the instruction sheet and insert the phrases from the cards when prompted. Rules state that the winner is the person who laughs loudest!

name: Mysteriet på Greveholm
description: The children Ivar and Lillan and the ghosts Jean and Steffan are trying to liberate the princess who the horrible count is holding captive.

name: Monopoly: Bayern
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Bayern (Bavaria), in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Barbie: Guess the Look!
description:
From the box:

"Guess your friends new look! Makeovers are hot, and you and your friend just got one! Can you guess what she looks like now? Hmmmm. Maybe she has green eyes ...or red hair ...or maybe she's wearing a hat! The first player to guess the others look wins. Be the first to guess each others new look by asking questions and recreating faces in compact mirrors."

The "mirrors" mentioned are actually easels with blank faces on them. The game comes with facial parts (not unlike a police sketch artist kit). So if your friend answers that she has green eyes, you'd place the "green eyes" piece onto the blank face etc.

name: Boohbah Get Up & Giggle Game
description:
This game is based on the children's TV characters. From the box:

You can be Humbah, Zumbah, Zing Zing Zingbah, Jumbah or Jingbah in this colorful get-up-and-move game! Travel around the spiral path and perform silly actions to collect as many tokens as you can. The player with the most tokens at the end is the winner!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Pony Express Game
description:
"Follow the riders from Sacramento to St. Jo -- If they can get through???" says the box.

One of four pony express riders tries to get through to St. Jo. Twelve Indian counters try to stop them. A piece is captured if landed upon by spun roll. Spinner has different movement points for express riders and Indians. Indians recycle through to the top of the board (St. Jo) via an "Indian trail." Appears to hale from the late 1950's or early 1960's, although the box bears a bar code.
publishers: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.

name: Lotsa Lotto
description: This is a simple children's matching game with a Sesame Street theme. Each player gets a gameboard depicting a location and a 3x3 grid with each space showing an item you might find there (for example, Cookie's Bakery has pictures of tasty things to eat). On your turn, pick up one picture token from the pile and check to see if the picture on the token matches one of the black and white pictures on your gameboard. If you have a match, place the token on the matching picture. If you don't have a match, you must offer the token to the other player to put on his or her gameboard. The first player to fill his or her gameboard with nine picture tokens wins.

name: Cruise
description: Cruise is first and foremost a card game. The cards depicts shares divided into different cruise-companies, and the players must collect the majority of the company. The deck also includes some special shares, "gold shares", which are more valuable than the other and gives the player a higher turnout when exchanging the shares for ships.

name: Überflieger: Kleine Solo-Spiele
description:
These are 5 different little solo games.

Überflieger
Unschlagbar
Exchange
...and 2 variants

name: Tak-Tik: Flotta kontra flyg
description: A Swedish Battleships clone, but giving one player an airforce instead of an opposing fleet. Printed in 1942.

name: Chart Moves
description:
Another roll and move game with spinners, dice, trivia, luck cards, etc...

Experience the deals and ordeals as you first play as a hustler then as a musician hopefully steering your tracks to the coveted 'No. 1'

name: War in Vietnam
description:
This is a Japanese wargame on the Tet Offensive during the Vietnam war.

One side plays the U.S. and the other plays the North Vietnamese.

Published as one of the Series: SS (Sho-Kikaku) in 1989.

Designed by Daisuke Sato.

name: War of the Star Slavers
description:
The third Meta-Galactic War ended with the realization by the belligerent empires that over 70% of their fleets had been destroyed. The decimation of their fleets also forced the contraction of their outer boundaries. Fearing that hostilities would be resumed before they could rebuild their fleets, the empires mutually agreed to bar all warships heavier than a cruiser from these liberated or abandoned (depending on your viewpoint) areas. Spontaneously the deserters, criminals, and other opportunists rose to fill this void. By preying on commercial ships and providing availability to now unobtainable or illegal items, they amassed great fortunes and others died in poverty or on the gallows.

War of the Star Slavers is a simulation of these violent times. As an empire player you must protect your commerce and prevent unrest among your populace so that you can rebuild your fleets. You must also protect yourself against the other empire as it is in his interest to see your economy fall apart as much as it is to defeat you on the field of battle.

The Slaver players must amass a fortune and retire before they are apprehended. The Slaver must pay for fuel, his crew, repairs on his ship, etc.

In other words every turn costs him money, but he can obtain large amounts of money by dealing in contraband or illegal acts. The greater the chance he takes the greater his return will be.

You can make any deals you like with whomever you choose. Anything you can get away with is valid. No act is too vile, no deal too dishonest.
categories: Economic, Pirates, Science Fiction, Transportation, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Paper-and-Pencil, Pick-up and Deliver, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Three Dimensional Movement, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up

name: Reise durch die Schweiz
description:
The game is a round trip through Switzerland, departing from and returning to Zürich. Distance is determined by die roll and there are no branches in the route, the only option being to choose to travel clockwise or counter-clockwise. Each player has six place cards, and if he or she stops at a place owned by another must pay that person one chip or miss a turn. The winner is the player with the highest total of chips plus bonus points gained by early completion of the journey.

Publication date is not specified but is probably early 1960s. The box cites both Franz Carl Weber/Jouets Weber (Swiss toy company and chain of shops) and Otto Maier Verlag (later Ravensburger: the box is printed "Ravensburger Spiele Nr. 23"). Otto Maier published a different game of the same name in 1891.

name: Dragon's Lair
description:
Based on the ground-breaking (at the time) Laserdisc-based videogame.

Race through the castle and rescue Princess Daphne.

Along with the standard die and cards to randomize the game, the board is also designed to shift. One layer is stationary, the other is mobile.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Escapades
description: This "game" actually consists of a box full of 300 activities, divided up into low, semi, and high action levels. The low action level activities may be questions, creative activities, or team-building exercises, while the high action level activities may consist of races or other athletic or dexterity games suitable for pre-adolescent parties.

name: Checards
description: The game of Checards is played on essentially a checker board but with cardboard tiles representing playing cards. One player takes the black suits and one the red suits. Once the cards are divided, they are mixed face down and placed onto the playing board so that neither player knows the value of any of the cards until they are placed face up one at a time on the board. Play proceeds by each player in turn moving a card piece forward in a diagonally direction one space. The idea is to eliminate all the opponents cards (cards are eliminated by "jumping" them, but a card is only eliminated if the jumping card is of higher or equal value than the card being jumped)

name: Save Your Planet
description:
From the box:

You are a special United Nations diplomat representing one of the five continents. Out of the blue, a planetary hazard looms and only swift strategic action will avert it. There are two races against time. First you must use your cunning and tactical diplomacy to outwit your opponents. In the meantime, however, the U.N. Special Envoy is following their course to save the world!

You must fly across the world in your specially commandeered aircraft, collecting and using solutions. You may have to cooperate with other diplomats, who may also have their own hidden agendas.

Meanwhile, the U.N. Special Envoy moves towards their destination and it is out of your control. Use your powers wisely.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Team-Based Game

name: The Royle Family
description:
Based on the UK Television Series of the same name following the exploits of the Manchester couch potato Royle family.

The object of the game is to answer trivia questions in order to collect Club biscuits. You miss turns if "Dave buys you a pint in The Feathers" or if "Barbara puts the kettle on for a brew......."

The mechanics are simple dice based movement with card drawing. Three decks of cards are used: Television Facts, Chance cards and the endearingly titled "My Arse" deck which takes it's name from Jim Royle's favourite saying.

Believe it or not there is a special edition which comes with a novelty toilet seat cover with a picture of Jim Royle on it!
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Know Canada's Heroes
description:
This game was manufactured in Paris, Ontario, Canada by the Walker Press, Ltd. in 1967 as one of the objects made available during the Canadian Centennial Celebration. The instructions and other text appears in both of Canada's official languages - English and French.

The flap-top box is 8.7cm long x 6cm wide x 1.3cm thick. The box includes the official Centennial Celebration symbol which can be seen in more detail on the back of each card.

There are 4 instruction cards in the deck which offer details for playing four different games with these cards. Each card is 8.5cm long x 5.5cm wide and features a date of note in Canada's history and a sketch of a person who played a role at that time in the history of Canada. Below the sketch are some historic details about the time period and the person's role. The various numbers and symbols on each card relate to playing the games.

This game is part of the collection of the Games Museum at the University of Waterloo in Waterloo, Canada.

name: Quick Draw McGraw Board Game
description:
Somewhat like snakes and ladders, the object of Quick Draw McGraw is to move your characters and be the first to reach the ranch. Alternate paths provide detours or shortcuts, and movement is governed by a spinner. The players' pieces are characters from the TV Cartoon show. This game is not the same as the 1960 Quick Draw McGraw Private Eye game, which used a similar mechanic but a completely different board.
Recommended Ages 5 - 10
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Read'em
description:
From the box:
Read'em is a family game that combines the skill of word building with the thrill of poker. The object is to win chips from other players by creating the best "hand" or by bluffing your opponents into thinking you have the best hand! Can a clever wordsmith outplay a wily poker bluff? Who'll win all the chips? That's the fun and excitement of Read'em!

Contents of the box
The game comes with a deck of 54 letter cards, poker chips and the rules to play 3 different poker games. You get the rules for Five Card Draw, Seven Card Stud and Hold'em (Hold'em is based on Texas Hold'em).
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Triune
description: Triune is an abstract strategy game in which players begin with a set number of soldiers (16 if 2 players, 12 if 3, 8 if 4) and attempt to reduce the other player(s) to 2 soldiers. You do so by building triunes (or rows of three soldiers in a line); each time you move one of your soldiers to create triune with two others, you get to remove one soldier belonging to an opponent. The game has a kind of Roman-ish theme, with legionnaire type soldier pieces.

name: Goren's Cutthroat Bridge for Three
description:
In the 1960s, Milton Bradley capitalized upon the popularity of bridge by publishing a series of games by bridge master Charles H. Goren. This is one of the more obscure titles in this series.

The game is described as, "An exciting, fast playing bridge game that scores differently and simply for 3, 4, or 5 players with one winner. It is strictly cutthroat in the bidding, but it creates a variety of partnerships against declarers after the bidding. The new and novel scoring system forces players to bid daringly, and sometimes play with exuberance."

The game includes a plastic playing platform with pegs to track bids, scoring, and card slots to facilitate dummy play.

name: Decisions
description:
From the publisher writeup:

"DECISIONS is an exciting and colorful new drug-prevention board game that teaches youngsters to use their own personal power to manage relationships that put them at risk. Perfect for use at home or in school, DECISIONS uses hard hitting, real-life scenarios to help participants experience the anxieties and emotions associated with making decisions about relationships that involve drugs."

The game places up to six players in various real-life drug-related situations and encourages discussion for these scenarios.

name: 1, 2, 3 Treasures in the Sea
description: A collection of three games, where kids search for treasures, collect silver and gold, or match colorful fish on the playing board. Intended to exercise and reinforce basic math counting and pattern recognition skills.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Number

name: Stops: North American Edition
description:
STOPS is an acronym for states, territories or provinces.
The STOPS NORTH AMERICAN EDITION game has 62 STOPS (or 62 possible answers), the names of the 50 states, the 10 provinces and two territories, all of which are printed directly on the colorful, dynamic game board. STOPS provides you with a clue, and you try to identify the STOP.

Blurb from reviewer:

"The award-winning trivia game that is challenging without being frustrating. Featuring a variety of questions that vary in difficulty, STOPS© is a game that can be played by geography experts and novices at the same time. The questions range from obscure facts that might be more suited to Jeopardy, to easier fare about landmarks, capitals and more. Testers gave high marks to the design of the board, and the simple directions. Many of the teachers at the testing centers told us that they believed STOPS© would make a great tool in their classrooms."
THE NATIONAL PARENTING CENTER, 1998 Spring Report

name: Unispel
description:
This game was made for the company Unilever.

Object of the game is to collect the most points by making rows of four or more by placing pieces of the same color on the board.

All players have seven pieces to pick from and after placement of the pieces, you fill your hand up to seven again.

A lot of products of Unilever are mentioned in this game.

name: Shopping Center Game
description:
A Baby Boomer children's game celebrating the new-fangled suburban Shopping Center. A spin and move game where you visit different stores and the first player to buy 6 items and get back to the parking lot wins.

From the bottom of the spinner

The Game of SHOPPING CENTER - for 2,3 or 4 Players

OBJECT: To take one purchase card from each store as a player moves his shopping cart around the board

WINNER: The first player to go out with six different purchase cards. Players take turns spinning and moving the number of spaces indicated on the spinner. A player may take a shopping card only when he stops on a space so marked. When a player has six different cards he moves, in his turn, toward the parking lot of his color. He must spin the correct number to put him out.

name: The Original Fortune Telling Board Game
description:
From the back of the box:

"The Original Fortune Telling Board Game " by Jennifer Sands is the only board game of its kind that combines a fun and safe methodology based on modern fortune card readings and empowered by real mystical stones. With a roll of the dice each player is whisked away on a journey to discover his or her special personalized fortune. Collect, win, lose or buy LOVE, MONEY, PEOPLE and Question cards in this fun and exciting game where all players win a real personalized fortune card reading of their own.

---

Each player rolls the die, moves his or her pawn, and then does what the landed on square tells them to. This is almost always either gaining or losing fortune telling cards (from four different decks - love, money, people, and questions) or empowering stones (which can be traded in for fortune telling cards). The rules state that the "object is for each player to collect as many fortune telling cards as possible"; but they also state that the winner "is the player who draws the last card," which ends the game and allows that player to discard up to three of their cards.

The real purpose is for each player to use the cards collected during the game to have their personal fortune told on the tarot-style card layout board.

If you believe in this stuff, you'll be happy to know that "all Jennifer Sands products are created with the assistance of professional psychics, fortune tellers and astrologers. All Jennifer Sands products use safe fortune telling methodologies."

If you don't believe in this stuff, you'll note "this product is for entertainment purposes only."

name: PiQadilly Circus
description:
From the publisher:
"PiQadilly Circus, the "Wonderful Wonderland Word Game," is alive with the spirit of Victorian whimsy. PiQadilly is both a thoughtful word game and a wild, spirited board game. This is a game that kids love to play, the perfect meeting place for adults and children. 2 to 4 players make crossword-style wordplays, then "riffle along the ruffle" in a madcap race. Word game and crossword enthusiasts will love it! (New Family Classic Game)"
categories: Card Game, Educational, Racing, Word Game

name: Primary Money Chase
description:
From the Publisher:

Young children learn to make change up to a dollar and recognize combinations of pennies, nickels dimes and quarters. For example: 3 nickels and 1 dime equal 1 quarter. The game is fun and competitive as players try to get around the board to their goal at the center of the board.

name: Scooby-Doo! Coolsville 500
description:
From the Publisher:

"Start your engines!" It's time for the Coolsville 500-the coolest, fastest race in town. Earn MPH cards that help speed you around the track, but be careful: the Monsters are in the pits! The first player to complete 5 laps wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Can't Cook, Won't Cook
description:
Based on the BBC Television Series of the same name, Can't Cook, Won't Cook is a lighthearted family game for 2 to 6 players Ages 10 and up

From the box:

"They say "If you can't stand the heat then get out of the kitchen!" the same is true of this exciting, fast paced family action packed board game.
It's a race to get your ingredients for a perfect meal traveling up and down the board a few times to collect them. sounds simple...well it would hardly be based on the hit TV show, if it were that easy!!
Firstly, it's against the clock, then it's against another player, then you have to answer some "Can't Cook" or "Won't Cook" questions, oh and did we mention you could be rolling the pastry, tossing the pancake, chopping the herbs, stirring the pans...."

The objective is to move around the board in order to collect points. Points are collected as you collect ingredient tokens. The game ends when the first player has collected all 5 ingredients. Movement is determined by dice roll with each player taking turns to have one minute (a sand timer is provided) to move and accomplish as much as they can.

The spaces on the board dictate the activities to be undertaken on them. These include:
- collecting an ingredient,
- pausing for a cup of tea (rolling until you get a 2),
- answering questions (cookery related - involving choosing your answer from a choice of four) or
- performing an action - stir the pan, roll the pastry, chop the herbs or toss the pancake (the equipment for which is all included with the game)
categories: Educational, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Delta Force
description:
DELTA FORCE - "The Game of Strategy, Confrontation and Capture. Outwit your opponent in a cunning campaign of sacrifice and counter-sacrifice."

Each player has fourteen triangular pieces numbered from 1 to 14. These are arranged in a matrix on each player's side of board.

Once placed the counters are moved forward towards the center of the board where counters from both sides come "face to face" in the "attack" position. The highest number wins each confrontation.

The winner is the player to capture the most Delta Force counters.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Height 203
description:
This game is on the climatic battle (or massacre) for Port Arthur during Russo-Japanese War.
Here Japanese lost horrendous casualties by the combination of fearsome firepower and solid entrenchment of Russians.
This battle became the prophesy of the trench warfare of WW1.

name: Wolfman Mystery Game
description:
Wolfman Mystery Game is a roll-and-move game where players eventually intersect 8 different locations on the game board, such as Skeleton Heap and Headhunters' Isle. There are no shortcuts or detours. Two spinners are provided, one for movement, and the other one for monster encounters.

Contents; Board, 4 player markers with different colored bases, and 2 spinners built into the game box insert.

name: Celebrity Monstars
description:
A game for 2-6 players Ages 12 and up

Components:
6 Operating Tables
1 D8
104 Cards

The object of the game is to build a Monstar from parts of well known (in 1989) (mostly UK) Celebrities.

Each Monstar requires 7 parts - head, chest, right arm, left arm, stomach, right leg and left leg, and must be constructed in sequence.

Body parts are dealt from the pack with each player only retaining 3 cards in his or her hand.

There are essentially only two options available to a player during their turn:
Lay a body part card, or
Roll the dice.

Dependant on the dice roll a player will either:
- Draw or nominate someone else to draw from a deck of "event" cards. This generally results in gaining or losing body parts for/from your Monstar.
- take a card from another player's hand
- Steal body parts from an opponent's "freezer".
- Steal body parts from an opponent's partilaly completed Monstar.

First to complete his or her Monstar and bring it to life through the use of an "Igor" card is the winner.

name: Consequences
description:
CONSEQUENCES - The Game of Decisions, Dilemmas and Deceit

From the Box

"What would be the consequences if you turned up at a fancy-dress party dressed as St George (complete with his dragon) only to discover everyone else in dinner dress?
Or what if you accidentally ran over the neighbor's cat, and no-one saw you do it?
Do you know what you would do?
Can you be sure your friends would do the same?
Find out in this hilarious board game of decisions, dilemmas and dishing the dirt.
Dishonesty has never been such fun!"

Contents:

Playing Board
200 Consequence Cards
24 Voting Cards
Special dice (4 faces show a "voting" symbol, 2 a "writing" symbol)
Playing pieces

During a player's turn the scenario on a Consequence Card is read out. Dependant on the role of a dice players then Vote (using three voting cards) on three possible answers (also on the card), or write down their answer.

Points are awarded for matching responses with other players, with progress being recorded by the movement of a playing piece on a score-board. The first player to 15 points is the winner.

name: IQuest
description:
Contents:

1 playing board
2,200 Questions and Answers
6 Playing "I"s
32 Scoring "Q"s
6 I agree / I Disagree cards
1 Timer

From the rule book:

"IQuest provides an absorbing challenge which allows players to explore their own abilities to think creatively. A range of fascinating word, number, shape and language puzzles in an intriguing variety of game categories awaits you for your quest through the IQuset maze. Whether you wrangle with a Rangle, or stumble over a Numble, IQuest provides fun and fascination for adults and children alike."

Players must correctly answer a series of questions, at least one in each of five categories, in order to progress towards the sunburst located in the middle of the board.

Players are allowed up to one minute to answer the questions, whilst the other players may choose to agree or disagree with the answer given. Correct answers result in movement of playing pieces and the receipt of Scoring "Q"s.

The first player to place his/her token on the sunburst and correctly answer an IQuest category question wins the game.

name: Europe 1483
description:
Europe 1483 is a medieval game of conquest and diplomacy. It represents Europe, North Africa and the Middle East in the year 1483 AD. Players compete cut-throat to expand their empires through war, economic development and diplomacy.

Game Includes:

432 Plastic Playing Tokens & Stickers
28" x 40" full color map
52 page rule booklet
1 d10
Territory and resource cut-out chits


Game has enough plastic tokens for 8 nations. Expansion sets allow players to expand that up to the full 28 nations.

The following description is for the PDF version:


Europe 1483 1st Edition is a 2-16 player strategy board game of diplomacy and conquest set in Europe in the year 1483 AD.1483 presents 10 major nations 6 minor nations that players may assume control of. Players must strive to increase the power of their nation or empire through conquest, trade, and a complex series of alliances with other players. Europe 1483 includes the following nations as player nations:


Kingdom of England
Kingdom of France
Kingdom of Spain
Holy Roman Empire
Kingdom of Poland & Lithuania
Kingdom of Hungary
Republic of Venice
Teutonic Order
Kingdom of Denmark
Regency of Sweden
Principality of Muscovy
Khanate of the Golden Horde
Ottoman Empire
Empire of the White Sheep Turks
Mamluk Sultanate of Egypt
Kingdom of Portugal


Europe 1483 comes complete with a 32" × 27" game map, in black and white using shading to clearly identify the different nations. This PDF also includes all necessary game charts and cut out game pieces for all nations, including neutral nations. Though you can easily forgo their use in favor of 3D figures such a metal miniatures, axis & allies playing pieces or some other suitable figure types.

Also look forward to the first editions of Asia 1483, Africa 1483, 1492: North America, and 1492: South America to create a monolithic medieval board gaming experience.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Simulation, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: American Trivia Game: Spirit of the United States
description: Players take turns getting a chance to answer questions in order to circle "flags". Score sheet shows both categories and flag markers that must be crossed off during game play when questions are answered correctly. First team to the agreed upon number wins. Play proceeds clockwise with players either answering the question correctly, or other teams getting a chance to "challenge" to have the opportunity to answer it themselves.

name: Triple Up
description: Triple Up consists of 40 different cards, each card has no numbers only 3 different symbols from a regular card deck (Heart, Spades Diamonds or Clubs) this is a trump and bidding game. The instructions suggest after all 13 tricks are played, score the game and 1st person to 500 points wins. This game can have almost as many variant card games as a regular deck of cards. Triple Up is a new and refreshing twist on classic trump/bidding card games.

name: Chasing Cogs
description:
From the KenMGames website:

Your machines are broken and you need to chase down some new cogs to fix them.
Trouble is, some one else might beat you to it ...

A tiny little game for two that can easily be kept in a purse or a wallet. Simple enough that the Rules are right here on this page (Don't worry, you won't forget them) ... But complex enough to give you some interesting choices in play!

name: Heartbeat
description:
What does your heart say, who is the date of your dreams?

Heartbeat is a game for girls where you get to date boys. You have to answer questions about things that can happen on dates and choose between your favorite boys. The electronic Heart tells you how well you and he match. Write entries of these guys down in your diary and when the game ends you’ll find out how it went for the other girls and who really is your dream date!

Recommended Ages 9 and up

name: Loser
description:
From the New World Games website:

A sneaky card game
for 4 or 6 players

Players will pick up and lay out cards, attempting to match four or five cards of the same value. If a player manages to do so, and secretly communicates it to his partner, they win the round. If the player is caught with four or five of a kind by the opponents first, his team loses the round. Each time a team loses, they get one or more letters. When they get enough to spell LOSER, the other team wins.

name: Popes & Princes
description: A political/military game based on scheming in medieval Europe.

name: Marine!
description:
A tactical game of U.S. Marine Corps operations.

Nine scenarios include rescue of PoW's, installation raids and an army/marine exercise.

Published as a magazine game in JagdPanther #10 which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.
categories: Modern Warfare, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Movement Points, Paper-and-Pencil, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Three Dimensional Movement, Zone of Control
publishers: Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: Dark Riders
description:
From the instructions:
"In 1600, deep in the valley of Charma, King Gambrel discovered a globe possessing mystical powers. He took the globe, which he named the Moonstone, back to his tower. Using the powers of the Moonstone, King Gambrel ruled long and wisely; however, four of his bravest knights became obsessed with the Moonstone and conspired to steal it.
King Gambrel discovered the plot, and using the Moonstone's supernatural powers he transformed the four knights into Dark Riders whose eternal task is to protect the Moonstone.
Recently, the Moonstone was rediscovered, still sealed away where King Gambrel had left it under the watchful eyes and powerful swords of the four Dark Riders. Only the most brave knights may challenge the Dark Riders for the possession of the Moonstone."
Dark Riders is similar to Pachisi or Sorry!, with mechanics in the rules to create blockades, or to send opponents back to "start". Your goal is to get to the tower in the center of the board, retrieve the Moonstone, and return it to your starting corner of the board while avoiding the Dark Riders and the other players.

name: Trailblazer
description:
Trailblazer is a rich U.S. history game that challenges your understanding of the American past while you blaze a trail across the country. By correctly answering questions about our diverse history from the pre-colonial period to the present, players advance across the map, accumulate Treasure Cards and risk their fortunes in a variety of adventures. You can choose to travel by canoe, horse, covered wagon, paddle boat, train or model T-Ford. And no matter ho much or how little you know about U.S. history, you'll learn something new with each play and have fun in the process!
Ages 8 and up

Related to:

Trailblazer

name: Words
description:
Words is a game in the 'big fun in a little box' series by Tobar Ltd. Like other games in the series, it comes in a large matchbox-like container and has nice miniature scoring pads and pencils. The main equipment are eight six-sided dice with a single letter on each face (3 of the dice have one blank face).

From the instructions:

"Words (any number of players)

The game is played over a number of rounds and each round needs to be timed. Usually one minute per round is adequate but this can be shortened / extended if preferred.

Players take it in turns to throw the eight dice. When the dice have stopped rolling, the round begins. The object is to make as many words, of three letters or more, as possible, from the other letters thrown.

Letters can only be used once per word. Blanks can be any letter from word to word. Pronouns and plurals are not allowed.

Players write the words constructed onto the score pad provided and at the end of each round, the score is calculated and added to each player's cumulative total. Points are scored as follows:

3 letter word - 1 point
4 letter word - 2 points
5 letter word - 3 points
6 letter word - 5 points
7 letter word - 7 points
8 letter word - 10 points

The winner is the first player to score 100 points, or whatever other total is pre-agreed by the participating players."

name: Blast! Card Game
description:
From the back of the box:

Blast! Card Game

Blast is the colorful, fast moving dice and card game where you can really find out who your friends are.

Each player has to match the throw of the die with the cards in their hand in order to get most points and win the game.

The game play is simple - just throw the dice and match the cards - a 'blue four' on the special color-coded dice together with a 'three' on the normal dice adds up to a 'BLUE SEVEN'. If you have the 'blue seven' card in your hand then you've scored seven points and it's your turn next with the dice.

But watch out! You're never sure of the winner until the count is up. With careful use of your action cards you can blast your opponents, lower their score , and make yourself the winner.


36 Dice Cards
19 Action Cards
Special color Coded Dice
Standard Dice
Rules Inside"


Listed as ages 8 to adult.
My Waddingtons edition states it is under license from Family Games, Canada.

name: Rettet die Wale!
description: This game is a contest between one player's whaling operation and the other player's Greenpeace activists. The Greenpeace player tries to block the whaling vessels with her boats. The whaler wins if he can maneuver around the Greenpeace boats and harpoon over half of the twelve whales.

name: Strawberry Shortcake Card Game Kitchen Capers
description:
You can make Strawberry Shortcake deliciously happy by collecting Recipe cards for her housewarming party. But watch out! The Purple Pieman will try to take your recipes from you. The player with the most Recipe cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Deal three piles of cards. Draw a card from any pile. If it is a recipe card, keep it. If it is a Purple Pieman you lose any Recipe cards you have drawn this turn. Keep drawing cards or stop at any time to make your Recipe cards "safe".
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Regn med Fætter Bjørn
description:
A little game teaching children basic math. Roll 3 dice and add any of the dice to reach the next number on a track going from 1 to 12 and down to 1 again. Dice can be used more than once, but only once in each combination. So for example rolling a 1, 2 and 4, you could jump to 1, then 2, 3 (2+1), 4, 5 (4+1), 6 (4+2), and finally to 7 (1+2+4) all in one go.

The advanced game lets you subtract numbers as well as add them, but in fact this makes the game easier and quicker.

With even more advanced rules you add multiplication and division.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Math, Number
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pepe e sale
description:
"Pepper and Salt" would be the name in English.

Is "the game of the recipes": with 7 recipe cards and 31 ingredients cards.

Very easy to learn and fast to play.

name: How to Host a Teen Mystery: Barbecue with the Vampire
description: "You are invited to attend a barbecue at the very spooky castle of rock superstar Killian Killagan. But when you arrive, you discover that someone at the barbecue is turning helpless citizens into bats. As you assume the role of one of these eight eerie characters and solve the mystery, you and your guests will enjoy hours of suspense and intrigue. All you need is a sense of humor and a light-hearted approach toward blackmail, theft and deceit. How To Host A Teen Mystery is so much fun it's almost criminal!"

name: Doubletake
description:
According to Sid Sackson's "A Gamut of Games":

Square cards show pictures of four different objects. Each picture appears three times and another three are very similar. Cards are played by covering an identical picture, or by bluffing if you can get away with it.

name: Hitting the Wall
description:
HITTING THE WALL is a simple roll and move boardgame with the theme of running the Marathon.

The board is divided into three parts
- an outer training circuit
- the Marathon course
- The "Wall"

Players have one playing piece which is used on the training circuit and Marathon course, and a counter which is used when they "Hit the Wall". Each player is also provided with a training schedule on which their training progress is recorded.

Players start the game by undertaking training which is conducted on the training circuit. They complete one lap of the training circuit, based on the results of dice rolls. The type of square landed on (e.g. hill training, training injury, new shoes etc..) is recorded on the training record, so that by the time that training is completed players will have had differing experiences as a result of their training.

Once all players have completed their training the Marathon race itself commences. Play progresses one throw at a time with penalties being dictated by the square on which the piece lands. Some penalties apply to all players, others only if the penalty is applicable to one of the events experienced during training (e.g. "Into the wall for injury" would only apply to a player who had been injured during training.) Once the penalty is spent the training incident is canceled on the training record.

Many of the penalties involve "hitting the wall" - that part of the Marathon where running becomes particularly difficult and you wonder whether it is all worthwhile. In the game this represented by having to complete a circuit of the 20 space "wall". The main playing pieces remains where it is on the Marathon circuit and the other counter is used to mark progress around the wall. Once the wall has been overcome the player may continue moving the runner on the Marathon track. The wall can be beaten by doing a complete circuit of the 20 spaces or by sacrificing any combination of two benefits (20 milers, hill training, drinks station) earned during the training session.

The winner is the first player to reach the finish of the Marathon.

name: Magnetic Dimensions
description:
In Magnetic Dimensions you get a Magnetic Hexagon shaped board, 106 magnetic pieces with 9 different shapes and sizes. The pieces are reversible and therefor give you 212 total pieces. The board is shaped like a hexagon and has reversible game pieces in nine different shapes. The game also comes with stylus with different ends to use as a placement and removal tool, a rulebook and Finally, you get an easel and a picture hanger to display your masterpiece after you have finished playing the game.

The game basis itself on the saying of "Is Magnetic Dimensions a game or is it art?" The answer in the manual to both of these questions is an unequivocal yes. Although in the rule book there are lots of options on how to play the game, it leaves it as an open form. You basically first take a piece and place it on the game board, and subsequently add another piece, then another and so on, until you have created your own design, or one of the shapes/designs shown in the Game manual. A Magnetic dimensions game takes as long as you need to create your picture through the use of all or some of the pieces.

Primarily the game is designed for one player, however there are several options/ideas for a 2 player game. For a two player version of the game you can allocate a certain number of pieces to each player, and then give a time limit on building something using opposite sides of the gaming board. Or you can have one design built, and then the other player tries to build it in the same amount of time or less.

The game has limitless options, and is a fun and relaxing game, as you create and challenge yourself within the game. You will see that there are many unique and very complicated ways you can create. This game has thousands of options that make players get deeply involved consumed by it.

In the end you will have to ask yourself... "Is it a game or is it Art?" In the end it really is both!

name: Clever Einkaufen
description:
Clever einkaufen(translates to "Shop cleverly") is a promotional game for the German mail order company Neckermann, produced by Ravensburger and designed by Wolfgang Kramer.

Each player starts with 5,000 DM and tries to buy as many products as possible with this.

To do this you move your pawn around the board which depicts the 20 products, of which only 5 are available at any time, connected by branching paths. If you reach one of the available products you may place one of your wooden markers, of which you have 4, on the product card. These cards show a price track for each player that allows them to reduce the price in five steps. At the end of your turn you may advance up to 2 of your markers one space on their price track. If you reach the end of the price track all players have to buy the product, even if they have no marker on that card. Each player pays the price that his marker indicates. The game ends as soon as one player is out of money. The player with the most money left wins. The game also includes random event cards and 'Stop' markers that may be used to block player movement.

name: Cash for Questions
description:
Do you feel lucky...?

Do you know when it's best to stick with what you've got...?

...or dare you gamble your winnings to double your money...?!

CASH FOR QUESTIONS is a nail-biting contest in which you compete to be the first to win a million. Answer correctly and you double your money...but make a slip and all that lovely lucre goes back to the banker!

With everyone competing at the same time, the game challenges you with hundreds of tricky questions, testing your knowledge to the limit.

Contents:
£10,000,000 in various denominations
Question book with 600 multiple choice questions
Buy-a-clue and Answer Book
Letter card deck (letters A, B and C representing possible answers to the questions)
"Clue solver" magnifying glass for use with the Answer Book.

name: Marathon
description:
Marathon was originally published by Minden Games as part of the Minden Sports Quad, 1991. It was republished in Counter Magazine Issue 6, August, 1999.

Marathon is a simple game based on one of the most imposing athletic events of all. Playable solitaire or against others, the object of the game is to complete the course in the fastest possible time. To reach this goal, players seek to utilize their cards in the best way possible in order to maximize their speed and endurance.

The game includes a map of the race course and rules. A token or marker, score pad and pencil, and a standard 52-card deck are needed for play. When playing with more than three players, two decks are required. The rules include several advanced options including designing your own course and designing your own runner.

name: The Green Game
description:
"THE GREEN GAME" is an educating and universal game of skill, strategy and chance designed for people young and old to have fun whilst gaining valuable knowledge of the fragile world we live in. The rules of the GREEN GAME are simple to follow and allow children of 8 years and over to play alongside adults."

The object of the game is to circulate the board answering questions, avoiding the pitfalls and collecting one of the subject cards of each topic.

The game contains 500 questions with 6 questions on each card (3,000 in total). The questions are in six different categories - Air, Water, Earth, Plants, Man Made, Pot Luck.

Players take it in turns to move and answer questions related to the subject category on which their piece lands. A player's turn continues for as long as he/she is able to successfully answer questions. A subject card is won when the question is correctly answered on a space that also contains a "?" symbol.

Certain spaces also require you to draw either an Evolution, Disaster, Lifeline or Pass card, and follow the instructions on it. These normally result in bonuses or penalties being applied to the player.

The winner is the first player to collect six different subject cards.

This game is endorsed by Survival for Tribal Peoples. Any proceeds from the game are used to aid tribal peoples throughout the world.

name: Presto Change-O
description: Children learn to make change, save money and start a business. With each move around the Presto Change-O game board, students are directed to either pay or receive money and make change.

name: Mega Golf
description: You play the part of a professional golf player taking part in a tournament. On each hole (on 18 different boards) the best player earns money. At the end, the player who has accumulated the most wins.

name: The Hockey Greats
description:
Hockey trivia board game. This is a trivia game for hockey fans who want to test their knowledge about the greatest sport in the world.

Over 3000 fascinating questions in 6 categories:

Goalies
Names & Numbers
Medley
Trades & Draft
Feats & Deeds
Playoffs

name: Speedway: The Great Motor Cycling Race Game
description:
1920s or 1930s game in the Harlesden series of games.
Made in England.

Simple roll and move mechanics with a long circular racetrack and metal motorcycle playing pieces.

name: The Flying Doctor Game
description:
Game based on the Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia. Draw 'mission cards' detailing cities that must be visited in order. Players' planes move along tracks that can be tailwinds or headwinds (increasing or decreasing speed), keeping track on a 'log book' sheet. Occasionally, a mission card may be a Wild Card, with special instructions. The board is a map of Australia divided into 'sections'. The objective of the game is to complete one mission in each section and return to the player's Home Base.

The Royal Flying Doctor Service began in Queensland in 1928, and was developed on a national basis during the 1930's. The service provides people of the Inland medical aid in emergencies, as well as comprehensive health care and community service. The Service today covers more than five million square kms, an area as large as Western Europe. The box states: "The Royal Flying Doctor Service is a beneficiary of this game."
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Sigma Omega
description:
Sigma Omega is two games in one: a tactical space combat system and an associated campaign system.

The tactical game uses three-dimensional Newtonian mechanics - every turn, each ship gets an acceleration on each axis which is added to the previous velocity. There are acceleration and maneuvering limits. Fighters are given the ability to alter facing somewhat independently of velocity, which affects combat - there is a section of invented maneuver combinations such as the "Cauchy Spiral."

The campaign game can be facilitated by a moderator, who creates a map and adjudicates the moves. There are rules for production, planetary invasion, and fairly complex rules for ship design if players do not like the twenty or so provided.

According to the rules, the game was originally "a set of guidelines for a computer simulation," which is apparent from the amount of arithmetic involved. In addition to the rulebook, counters, base ships (which must be cut out), and fighter sighting templates (ditto), the game includes an order sheet of programs for Texas Instruments calculators which would implement various game calculations.
mechanics: Critical Hits and Failures, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simultaneous Action Selection, Three Dimensional Movement, Variable Set-up

name: Clean-Up
description:
"A tour of the town reveals all the trash. Equipped with trash cans, trees, and flowers, players engage in a clean-up and beautification program."

Materials: Game board, trash can, tree and flower accessories, "easy-to-assemble" town.

name: Dignity
description:
"Dignity is a human relations board game which seeks to portray the frustrations of people in the ghettos. The object of the game is to reach a square called Dignity. To get there, a player, who is given five cards and $100, tries to avoid Shanty Town, Housing Projects, Skid Row and other unpleasant places. A shortcut through Uncle Tom's Limbo precludes playing Freedom Move cards, generally helpful in the game. There is another shortcut through the University, but that costs $2000, which is difficult to acquire. Players will encounter setbacks as well as unexpected opportunities to reach Dignity."

Materials: Game board, cards, play money, accessories.

name: The All New Brit Quiz Game
description:
One (the third(?)) in a series of simple quiz games that require, as the name suggests, knowledge of British trivia...

Players take turns to roll a die and move that number of spaces round the board. The player then tries to answer a question determined by both the colour of the space he or she lands on, and the actual number rolled on the die. If the question is answered correctly the player moves forwards an additional three spaces as a reward. There is no penalty for getting the answer wrong.

The question categories are:

Orange - History & This And That
Yellow - People
White - Places
Green - Showbiz
Blue - Best of British luck
Red - Sport
Brown - Up The Creek

The questions for Sport, History & This & That, People, Places and Showbiz all require straight answers to a straight forward question.

The questions for the Best of British luck are in a different format with 6 different types available - Multiple Choice, Odd Man Out, Missing Letters, Anagrams, Whereabouts, and Draw - with the last four of these categories being conducted against a 30 second timer.

'Up The Creek' is a special category that asks the player to perform an activity rather than answer a question. If the player fails to carry out the activity to the satisfaction of the other players, or refuses to even try, he or she has to move backwards three spaces.

The winner is the first player to complete a circuit of the track around the board.

name: Point Zero
description:
POINT ZERO - The UNICEF Strategy Game is a roll and move and tile placement board game simulating the development of an under-developed region of the world by UNICEF.

The board is divided into four regions, one for each player, representing a village in the African Bush, the Amazon Basin, the Sahel Belt or South East Asia. An information card for each area provides details of the kind of assistance required and the types of trained personnel required to provide it - this varies from region to region.

Players take it in turns to move their "Community Leader" around the outer circuit of the board the number of spaces determined by the roll of either one or two dice. In so doing the players collect (and on occasion lose) a variety of Community workers, Medics, Technicians, Teachers and Social workers. The directions in the spaces also initiate good or bad events in the region.

At various points on the board these helpers can be used to develop part of their village. The player developing the Sahel Belt, for example, will need to construct a safe water supply, Milk Processing Plant, Health Care Center, School etc... Construction requires then right compliment of experts and may also cost points which are earned through completing circuits of the board.

The construction undertaken and equipment purchased is represented on the board by a series of jig-saw pieces which are placed within a frame that is positioned over the game board. The pieces can be added into the frame in any order, but successful redevelopment of a village will require a total of 11 pieces.

The winner is the player that is first to have successfully reconstructed his or her village by covering the developing area with 11 reconstruction pieces.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Royal Toad
description:
From the publisher:

"In Royal Toad, Prince and Princess cards are chosen from each player's hand to find their noble matches. The player who holds on to the Royal Toad card before it "hops" off is the winner!"

A SimplyFun version of the card game "Old Maid," with the twist that players are trying to keep the "Royal Toad" instead of get rid of it.

name: Cars, Boats & Trains
description:
From the box:

A domino game. In this simple game of observation, children lay brightly colored picture cards of cars, boats, trains, fire engines and helicopters on the table, next to other cards that show the same picture. The first player to get rid of all his or her cards is the winner.

Ages 3 - 6

name: Mirror Mania
description:
Take the driver's seat in this sensational, brain-teasing game! Just follow the road from start to finish. Sounds simple…but can it be done using a reflected image? Whether alone, with friends, or at a party, Mirror Mania is sure to bring hours of fun, laughter and excitement.

Contents: Easy-to-Assemble Game Tray, Play sheets, 2 Felt Tip Pens, Instruction Sheet.

Follow the simple instructions for the easy-to-assemble game tray. Choose a play sheet and pen. Now you're ready to get behind the wheel! Observe the reflected image through the eye holes on the viewer panel. Place a pen at Start and go…Oops! Stay on the road! Fun to do, hilarious to watch. The eyes see an image the hand won't follow. Your mind says go, but your hand says no!

name: Somewhere in the Rockies
description: We are partners in the TK&RL Transport Business, with our own lines of trains and trucks for collecting and delivering various goods to Mr. Big's coastal warehouses. Mr. Big pays us well for everything we bring in plus bonuses for filling each warehouse. The risks are great, what with the roads and rails getting wiped out by snow storms and rock slides, not to mention government cutbacks leaving the infrastructure in dangerous shape. Only partners with nerves of steel and alert brains need apply for the job. If you have what it takes, join us in a railway and trucking adventure.

name: Pioch'à Mots
description:
The game consists of a deck of cards with letters on them. There are black letters, red letters and 2 special joker cards (which can be used as any letter).

Each player in turns flips over the top card of the deck and puts it in the play ares (visible for all players). The first player who is able to form a word (minimum length : 4 letters) with the revealed cards, gains points. The longer the word, the more points are scored. There's a bonus if the word is entirely made of letters of the same color.

You play until you reach a number of points agreed upon before play starts.
